Compare-object seems to sort both arrays before comparing them, usually as strings.  But the sort algorithm seems very slow.  Pre-sorting both arrays with sort-object is much faster.  Even without pre-sorting, these two arrays are considered equal by compare-object.

EDIT:
Ok, so maybe compare-object doesn't sort the two files, but by default matches every line in one file with every line in the other file, unless setting the -syncwindow?  If anything, this shows how confusing this command is, and how slow it can be with big files.  I've seen people assume that every object property is compared by default.

## Steps to reproduce

```powershell
$a1 = 1..45kb
$a2 = 45kb..1
measure-command { compare ($a1) ($a2) } | % seconds
```

## Expected behavior

```none
1
```

## Actual behavior

```none
25
```

Workaround, about 25x faster.  I tried larger arrays, 1..700kb, without the sort, but after 8 minutes I gave up.  With sorting, it took about 15 seconds.

```powershell
$a1 = 1..45kb
$a2 = 45kb..1
measure-command { compare ($a1|sort) ($a2|sort) } | % seconds
```
